statement.p:
Suppose that A and its reduced row echelon form are
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 0 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \amp 6 \\ 0 \amp -4 \amp -1 \amp 7 \amp 0 \amp -16 \\ 0 \amp 6 \amp 0 \amp -12 \amp 3 \amp 15 \\ 0 \amp 4 \amp -1 \amp -9 \amp 0 \amp 8 \\ \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \amp 3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \amp 0 \amp 4 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
The null space \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^p for what p? The column space \col(A) is a subspace of \real^p for what p?
What are the dimensions \dim~\nul(A) and \dim~\col(A)?
Find a basis for the column space \col(A).
Find a basis for the null space \nul(A).

li.p: \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^6 and \col(A) is a subspace of \real^4.
Because there are three pivot positions, we see that \rank(A) = 3. Therefore, \dim~\nul(A) = 6-3=3 and \dim~\col(A)=3.

A basis for \col(A) is given by the columns of A that contain pivot positions. Therefore, a basis is
\fourvec{2}{-4}{6}{4}, \fourvec{0}{-1}{0}{-1}, \fourvec{0}{0}{3}{0}\text{.}
\nul(A) is a subspace of \real^6 and \col(A) is a subspace of \real^4.
\dim~\nul(A) = 3 and \dim~\col(A)=3.

statement.p:
Suppose that
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp -4 \\ -2 \amp -1 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp -1 \amp -2 \end{array}\right] .
Is the vector \threevec{0}{-1}{-1} in \col(A)?
Is the vector \fourvec{2}{1}{0}{2} in \col(A)?
Is the vector \threevec{2}{-2}{0} in \nul(A)?
Is the vector \fourvec{1}{-1}{3}{-1} in \nul(A)?
Is the vector \fourvec{1}{0}{1}{-1} in \nul(A)?

li.p: Yes. This vector is a column of A so it may be written as a linear combination of the columns of A.
No. Vectors in \col(A) must be three-dimensional.
No. Vectors in \nul(A) must be four-dimensional.
Yes, because this vector, when multiplied by A, gives \zerovec.
No, because this vector, when multiplied by A, does not give \zerovec.
Yes
No
No
Yes
No

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response. Unless otherwise stated, assume that A is an m\times n matrix.
If A is a 127\times 341 matrix, then \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^{127}.
If \dim~\nul(A) = 0, then the columns of A are linearly independent.
If \col(A) = \real^m, then A is invertible.
If A has a pivot position in every column, then \nul(A) = \real^n.
If \col(A) = \real^m and \nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}, then A is invertible.

li.p: False. \nul(A) is a subspace of \real^{341}.

True. In this case, the only solution to the homogeneous equation A\xvec=\zerovec is the zero solution \xvec=\zerovec. This means that every column has a pivot position so the columns are linearly independent.
False. The matrix A is not necessarily a square matrix.
False. If A has a pivot position in every column, then \nul(A) = \{\zerovec\}.

True. Since \col(A)=\real^m, we know that A has a pivot position in every row. Since \nul(A)=\{\zerovec\}, we know that A has a pivot position in every column. Therefore, A must be a square matrix and invertible.
False
True
False
False
True

statement.p:
Explain why the following statements are true.
If B is invertible, then 
ul(BA) = 
ul(A).
If B is invertible, then \col(AB) = \col(A).
If A\sim A', then 
ul(A) = 
ul(A').

li.p: If BA\xvec=\zerovec, then A\xvec=\zerovec if B is invertible.

The column space consists of all the vectors \bvec for which A\xvec=\bvec is consistent. We can rewrite this condition as AB(B^{-1}\xvec)=\bvec, which means that A\xvec=\bvec is consistent exactly when AB\xvec=\bvec is.
If A\sim A', then A and A' have the same reduced row echelon form, which determines \nul(A).
If BA\xvec=\zerovec, then A\xvec=\zerovec if B is invertible.

The column space consists of all the vectors \bvec for which A\xvec=\bvec is consistent. We can rewrite this condition as AB(B^{-1}\xvec)=\bvec, which means that A\xvec=\bvec is consistent exactly when AB\xvec=\bvec is.
If A\sim A', then A and A' have the same reduced row echelon form, which determines \nul(A).

statement.p:
For each of the following conditions, construct a 3\times 3 matrix having the given properties.
\dim~\nul(A) = 0.
\dim~\nul(A) = 1.
\dim~\nul(A) = 2.
\dim~\nul(A) = 3.

li.p: \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 4 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 4 \amp -1 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a 3\times 4 matrix.
Is it possible that \dim~\nul(A) = 0?
If \dim~\nul(A) = 1, what can you say about \col(A)?
If \dim~\nul(A) = 2, what can you say about \col(A)?
If \dim~\nul(A) = 3, what can you say about \col(A)?
If \dim~\nul(A) = 4, what can you say about \col(A)?

li.p: No. There are more columns than rows so there must be at least one column without a pivot position.
Remember that we have \dim~\col(A) + \dim~\nul(A) = 4. Therefore, we have \dim~\col(A) = 3 in this case, which implies that \col(A) = \real^3.
Here, \dim~\col(A) = 2 so \col(A) is a plane in \real^3.
Here, \dim~\col(A) = 1 so \col(A) is a line in \real^3.
Here, \dim~\col(A) = 0 so \col(A)=\{\zerovec\}.
No
\col(A) is a plane in \real^3
\col(A) is a line in \real^3
\col(A)=\{\zerovec\}.

statement.p:
Suppose we have the vectors
\vvec_1 = \threevec{2}{3}{-1},~ \vvec_2 = \threevec{-1}{2}{4},~ \wvec_1 = \fourvec{3}{-1}{1}{0},~ \wvec_2 = \fourvec{-2}{4}{0}{1}
and that A is a matrix such that \col(A)=\laspan{\vvec_1,\vvec_2} and \nul(A) = \laspan{\wvec_1,\wvec_2}.
What are the dimensions of A?
Find such a matrix A.

li.p: Since \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are three-dimensional vectors, A must have three rows. Since \wvec_1 and \wvec_2 are 4-dimensional, A must have four columns. Alternatively, we know that \dim~\nul(A) = 2 and \dim~\col(A) = 2. Therefore, the number of columns is n=\dim~\nul(A) + \dim~\col(A) = 4. Hence, A is a 3\times4 matrix.

We can use \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 as the first two columns of A. We also know that A\wvec_1=\zerovec and A\wvec_2=\zerovec. If we call the other two columns \vvec_3 and \vvec_4, then A\wvec_1=\zerovec implies that 3\vvec_1-\vvec_2+\vvec_3 = \zerovec so that \vvec_3 = \threevec{-7}{-7}{7}. Since A\wvec_2 = \zerovec, we have -2\vvec_1+4\vvec_2 + \vvec_4=\zerovec, which says that \vvec_4=\threevec{8}{-2}{-18}. This gives
A = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 2 \amp -1 \amp -7 \amp 8 \\ 3 \amp 2 \amp -7 \amp -2 \\ -1 \amp 4 \amp 7 \amp -18 \\ \end{array}\right]\text{.}

statement.p:
Suppose that A is an 8\times 8 matrix and that \det A = 14.
What can you conclude about \nul(A)?
What can you conclude about \col(A)?

solution.p: We know that A is invertible so \nul(A)=\{\zerovec\} and \col(A) = \real^8.

statement.p:
Suppose that A is a matrix and there is an invertible matrix P such that
A = P~\left[\begin{array}{rrr} 2 \amp 0 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp -3 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right]~P^{-1} .
What can you conclude about \nul(A)?
What can you conclude about \col(A)?

solution.p: We know that \det A = -6 so A is invertible. Therefore, \nul(A)=\{\zerovec\} and \col(A)=\real^3.

statement.p: In this section, we saw that the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec is a subspace of \real^p for some p. In this exercise, we will investigate whether the solution space to another equation A\xvec = \bvec can form a subspace.

Let's consider the matrix
A = \left[\begin{array}{rr} 2 \amp -4 \\ -1 \amp 2 \\ \end{array}\right] .
Find a parametric description of the solution space to the homogeneous equation A\xvec = \zerovec.
Graph the solution space to the homogeneous equation to the right.
A two dimensional coordinate grid and axes.
A two dimensional diagram with a 1\times1 coordinate grid and a set of axes. The horizontal and vertical ranges of the viewing window start at -4 and end at 4.
Find a parametric description of the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \twovec{4}{-2} and graph it above.
Is the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \twovec{4}{-2} a subspace of \real^2?
Find a parametric description of the solution space to the equation A\xvec=\twovec{-8}{4} and graph it above.
What can you say about all the solution spaces to equations of the form A\xvec = \bvec when \bvec is a vector in \col(A)?
Suppose that the solution space to the equation A\xvec = \bvec forms a subspace. Explain why it must be true that \bvec = \zerovec.

li.p: The solution space forms a line through the origin.
The solution space has the parametric description \xvec=\twovec{2}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}, which is a line parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
This cannot form a subspace since it does not contain the vector \zerovec.

The solution space has the parametric description \xvec=\twovec{-4}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}, which is a line parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation. The graph of the solution spaces is shown below.
They are all parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
If the solution space is a subspace, then \xvec=\zerovec must be in the solution space. This means that A\xvec = A\zerovec = \zerovec = \bvec.
The solution space forms a line through the origin.
No
\xvec=\twovec{-4}{0}+x_2\twovec{2}{1}. The graph of the solution spaces is shown below.
They are all parallel to the solution space to the homogeneous equation.
\xvec=\zerovec must be in the solution space.
